Articles: {"abstract": " Berkshire Hathaway, the investment vehicle of famed value investor Warren E. Buffett, has revealed its end-of-2006 stock positions, including its $843 million stake in Minneapolis-based U.S. Bancorp. From January through September of last year, Berkshire built up its U.S. Bancorp holdings by 23.3 million shares, representing a 1.3 percent stake in the bank, the nation\u2019s sixth-largest by assets. Because so many investors watch Mr. Buffett\u2019s portfolio, regulators sometimes allow his firm to delay disclosures of its trades in an effort to forestall market mimicry. {"abstract": "While many companies are starting tie the pay of chief executives to stock performance, don\u2019t expect Berkshire Hathaway to jump on the bandwagon anytime soon. For Warren Buffett, Berkshire\u2019s chief executive, such an arrangement would be a gold mine. His company\u2019s stock is valued at more than $106,000 a share. And last year, it rose 24 percent in value. {"abstract": " Blackstone Group, confirming a firestorm of speculation, said Thursday it would seek an initial public offering that would value the firm at as much as $40 billion. The preliminary prospectus offered a first glimpse inside Blackstone\u2019s closely guarded money machine, which churned out $2.3 billion in profit in 2006. {"abstract": "Berkshire Hathaway, the company controlled by Warren E. Buffett, says it has acquired a 10.9 percent stake in Burlington Northern Santa Fe, becoming the railroad company\u2019s largest shareholder. Berkshire owned 39,027,430 shares of Burlington Northern with a market value of $3.23 billion as of April 5, according to a filing Friday with the Securities and Exchange Commission. {"abstract": "Warren E. Buffett sold about 1.1 billion Hong Kong dollars worth ($141 million) of shares in the PetroChina Company.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2007/09/13/business/worldbusiness/13fobriefs-BUFFETTSELLS_BRF.html", "snippet": "Warren E. Buffett sold about 1.1 billion Hong Kong dollars worth ($141 million) of shares in the PetroChina Company.", "lead_paragraph": "Warren E. Buffett sold about 1.1 billion Hong Kong dollars worth ($141 million) of shares in the PetroChina Company, his second sale in two months, amid calls for United States investors to reduce holdings in China\u2019s biggest oil producer because of its links to Sudan. Mr. Buffett\u2019s holding company, Berkshire Hathaway, sold 92.66 million shares at an average of 11.473 Hong Kong dollars on Aug. 29, a Hong Kong stock exchange filing showed. That reduced his stake to 9.72 percent of the stock not controlled by the Chinese government from 10.16 percent. Berkshire made a more than sixfold gain on the sale, having bought its PetroChina stake for less than 1.70 Hong Kong dollars a share in April 2003.", "print_section": "C", "print_page": "10", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "China: Buffett Sells Petrochina Shares", "kicker": "World Business Briefing", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "China: Buffett Sells Petrochina Shares", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "organizations", "value": "PetroChina Company Limited", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Berkshire Hathaway Incorporated", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "persons", "value": "Buffett, Warren E", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2007-09-13T04:00:00+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "World Business", "byline": {"original": "By Bloomberg News", "person": [{"firstname": "Bloomberg", "middlename": null, "lastname": "News", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "Brief", "_id": "nyt://article/df63af74-2a30-59e0-9855-3e68ac65b5cc", "word_count": 123, "uri": "nyt://article/df63af74-2a30-59e0-9855-3e68ac65b5cc"}

{"abstract": "Berkshire Hathaway, controlled by Warren E. Buffett, sold shares of the PetroChina Company, the biggest oil producer in China, valued at 2.8 billion Hong Kong dollars ($364 million). {"abstract": "Four times a year, fans of Warren Buffett \u2014 and there are a lot of them \u2014 rush to see which stocks his Berkshire Hathaway has bought in the latest quarter, in hopes of getting a good investment tip or two. Last week, there was a flurry of excitement about CarMax, the seller of used cars, because it appeared that the legendary investor had added nearly 14 million CarMax shares to his portfolio. That was enough to send CarMax\u2019s stock price soaring 7.5 percent in much heavier-than-normal trading.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2007/11/20/buffett-and-carmax-less-than-meets-the-eye/", "snippet": "", "lead_paragraph": "Four times a year, fans of Warren Buffett \u2014 and there are a lot of them \u2014 rush to see which stocks his Berkshire Hathaway has bought in the latest quarter, in hopes of getting a good investment tip or two. {"abstract": "Transatlantic Holdings and Allied World Assurance called off their proposed $2.94 billion merger after the two insurers faced stiff shareholder opposition.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2011/09/17/business/transatlantic-and-allied-cancel-merger-plans.html", "snippet": "Transatlantic Holdings and Allied World Assurance called off their proposed $2.94 billion merger after the two insurers faced stiff shareholder opposition.", "lead_paragraph": "Transatlantic Holdings and Allied World Assurance called off their proposed $2.94 billion merger on Friday after the two insurers faced stiff shareholder opposition and two rival bids for Transatlantic. Transatlantic has been fending off a higher $3.01 billion takeover bid by another reinsurer, Validus Holdings, and had been in talks with a unit of Berkshire Hathaway that had offered $3.25 billion. {"abstract": "Shareholders liked Warren Buffett\u2019s stock buyback decision, but what\u2019s good for Mr. Buffett might not be so good for other corporate bosses.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2011/09/27/business/how-to-mimic-berkshires-bet-breakingviews.html", "snippet": "Shareholders liked Warren Buffett\u2019s stock buyback decision, but what\u2019s good for Mr. Buffett might not be so good for other corporate bosses.", "lead_paragraph": "Warren Buffett isn\u2019t too old to try something new. His Berkshire Hathaway conglomerate said on Monday that it might buy back an unlimited amount of both classes of shares, at up to a 10 percent premium over book value. Many investors like to copy what Mr. Buffett does, but stock repurchases are best left to the Oracle of Omaha. {"abstract": "Also, a big deal involving Taylor Swift will finally give labels and performers a cut of radio revenue.", "web_url": "https://mediadecoder.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/06/06/the-breakfast-meeting-warren-buffett-likes-newspapers-and-barbara-walters-apologizes/", "snippet": "Also, a big deal involving Taylor Swift will finally give labels and performers a cut of radio revenue.", "lead_paragraph": "Taylor Swift and her record label may be reversing decades of music economics with a new deal struck with Clear Channel, the nation\u2019s largest radio operator, writes Ben Sisario. The deal would give the label and performer royalties for traditional radio play \u2014 something the music business has long fought for and never received. In return, the label agreed to accept a cut for online radio play (which does award royalties to performers and labels), giving Clear Channel at least some measure of predictability in online payments. Online play is a tiny part of Clear Channel\u2019s business but the company saw an opportunity to preemptively control costs.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": {"abstract": "Berkshire Hathaway said on Friday that it had agreed to buy The Waco Tribune-Herald, which has a daily circulation of 34,000, to expand in Texas.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2012/06/23/business/media/berkshire-hathaway-buys-the-waco-tribune-herald.html", "snippet": "Berkshire Hathaway said on Friday that it had agreed to buy The Waco Tribune-Herald, which has a daily circulation of 34,000, to expand in Texas.", "lead_paragraph": "Berkshire Hathaway said on Friday that it had agreed to buy The Waco Tribune-Herald to expand in Texas. Berkshire is buying the newspaper, which has a daily circulation of 34,000, from the Robinson family, the company said. Terms were not disclosed. Warren E. Buffett, Berkshire\u2019s chief, has said that newspapers must rethink whether to offer free content on the Internet, and that publications with a community focus can thrive where there is little competition. "nyt://article/dded4c99-30a3-5b6b-86be-4a3039224f2c"}, {"abstract": "Hedge fund managers are getting richer. | Bayer is buying Merck\u2019s consumer care business. | At Berkshire Hathaway, a culture of trust. | Barclays\u2019 first-quarter earnings declined.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2014/05/06/morning-agenda-a-haul-for-hedge-fund-moguls/", "snippet": "Hedge fund managers are getting richer. | Bayer is buying Merck\u2019s consumer care business. | At Berkshire Hathaway, a culture of trust. | Barclays\u2019 first-quarter earnings declined.", "lead_paragraph": "Hedge fund managers, who heavily populate the so-called 1 percent in the United States, are getting richer. The 25 highest-earning hedge fund managers in the United States took home a total of $21.15 billion in compensation in 2013, according to an annual ranking published on Tuesday by Institutional Investor\u2019s Alpha magazine, DealBook\u2019s Alexandra Stevenson writes. The payday, earned in a year when most hedge fund managers fell short of market performance, is the highest since 2010 and 50 percent more than in 2012. No women placed among the top 50.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "A Big Haul for Hedge Fund Moguls", "kicker": "DealBook", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [], "pub_date": "2014-05-06T11:49:17+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Sydney Ember", "person": [{"firstname": "Sydney", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Ember", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/a8ff57ec-dccf-536a-ad16-f051bb3aeff1", "word_count": 1854, "uri": "nyt://article/a8ff57ec-dccf-536a-ad16-f051bb3aeff1"}]

Buffett promotes the Berkshire Hathaway brand. | Calculating the cost of Ebola | Derivatives change only goes so far.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2014/10/14/morning-agenda-jpmorgan-swings-to-a-profit/", "snippet": "JPMorgan Chase posts a third-quarter profit. | Warren E. Buffett promotes the Berkshire Hathaway brand. | Calculating the cost of Ebola | Derivatives change only goes so far.", "lead_paragraph": "JPMorgan Chase swung to a profit in the third quarter, but the announcement on Tuesday morning was marred by an early release of the results on a third-party website, DealBook\u2019s Nathaniel Popper writes. The bank earned $5.57 billion in the quarter, or $1.36 a share, compared with a loss of $380 million in the quarter a year earlier, when the bank booked $7.2 billion in legal costs. Net revenue rose 5 percent, to $25.2 billion, from the third quarter of 2013. The earnings fell short of analysts\u2019 estimates of $1.38 a share, according to a survey by Thomson Reuters. Earnings were reduced by $1.1 billion in legal expenses, or 26 cents a share, after taxes.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Morning Agenda: JPMorgan Swings to a Profit", "kicker": "DealBook", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [], "pub_date": "2014-10-14T11:58:04+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Sydney Ember", "person": [{"firstname": "Sydney", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Ember", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/d6812ea5-1cd4-52e2-a274-5845639eb675", "word_count": 2416, "uri": "nyt://article/d6812ea5-1cd4-52e2-a274-5845639eb675"}]

Ackman, the billionaire hedge fund investor, attempted to downplay the magnitude of Valeant\u2019s problems in a recent conference call.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2015/10/31/business/dealbook/trying-in-vain-to-put-a-positive-spin-on-valeants-troubles.html", "snippet": "William A. Ackman, the billionaire hedge fund investor, attempted to downplay the magnitude of Valeant\u2019s problems in a recent conference call.", "lead_paragraph": "The hedge fund founder William A. Ackman\u2019s defense of Valeant Pharmaceuticals was bold but unpersuasive. Mr. Ackman, who leads Pershing Square Capital, says that Valeant, a drug giant worth $34 billion, is a victim of bad public relations, na\u00efve investors and jealous rivals. He even compared his stake to one of the riskiest but most successful bets ever made by Warren E. Buffett, the Berkshire Hathaway chief. In reality, the company is flawed in ways that Mr. Ackman\u2019s pep talk won\u2019t fix.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [{"rank": 0, "subtype": "xlarge", "caption": null, "credit":
